Orland has been engaged in business for over one year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.  He has always invested his income back into his business, and he hopes to expand into a big piggery, with 10 piglets.

Additionally, Orland's success has enabled him to support his parents' daily basic needs. 

Orland expresses his utmost thanks to the people who supported his first cycle loan.

loans.use: to invest and expand his business.

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en: Rosalina is 57 years old and married with 7 children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Rosalina is borrowing PHP 10,000 from Kiva's partner, NWTF, to buy more feed and vitamins for her pigs. Rosalina has been raising pigs for 3 years and also earns additional income from selling coconuts. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough to build a house for her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Lisbeth

texts.es:
La señora Lizbeth es casada con el señor Isidro y con quien procreo tres hijos que a un están a su responsabilidad.

    Ella solicito el préstamo para invertirlo en  la compara de  materiales  como son: tintes, tratamiento de capilar, decolorantes, entre otros en donde lleva  trabajando hace  cuatro años y nueve meses en donde comenta que el va bien ya que  ha logrado comprar más materiales.

   Quien la animo a esta actividad fue ella mismo ya que estudio belleza y al terminar decidió   poner  su propia estética  para así tener un poco mas de ingresos  para su hogar y su negocio que es con lo que tanto la  ayuda.

   Lo que más desea es que con esta pequeña actividad pueda ir mejorando  un poco más su negocio y así sus clientes estén mas cómoda con  la a envió que se les brinda.
texts.en:
Sra. Lizbeth is married to Sr. Isidro and they are responsible for their three children. She is requesting a loan to invest in the purchase of supplies such as dyes, hair treatments, bleaching agents, and other items. Lizbeth has been working for four years and nine months. She says that she has done very well because she has been able to buy more materials.

Lizbeth was excited about having a business because she studied cosmetology. Upon finishing her studies, she decided to open her own aesthetics salon so that she could generate a little more household income. Her business has helped in this manner.

What she wants most is to make a few small improvements to her business. She wants her customers to be more comfortable in the environment that she provides them.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Sandra

texts.es: Sandra de 33 años de edad, vive con su cónyuge y sus dos hijos en las edades de 2 y 8 años, en el municipio de Soledad, tierra de las butifarras, (embutidos artesanales) ubicada  a 15 minutos de la ciudad de Barranquilla. Allí se dedica al mejoramiento de la imagen personal y profesional de sus clientes, ofreciéndoles cortes de cabello, masajes, peinados, arreglo de uñas de las  manos y de los pies y tratamientos capilares,  que ella aprendió para emprender su propio negocio y generar ingresos importantes para el buen desempeño de su familia, desde hace seis años, en un local  que organizó   en su propia vivienda;    su primera clientela estaba conformada, por buenos vecinos, familiares y amigos cercanos, que aun conserva, y que diariamente son los responsables del incremento de su mercado. En la actualidad su sueño de crecimiento, va mas lejos  que sus posibilidades personales, pues su clientela aumenta  cada día y las necesidades de capital de trabajo de Sandra se hacen cada vez mas evidentes,  porque su propio dinero es insuficiente,  para atender la demanda de sus clientes, especialmente en la época de las fiestas familiares mas importantes del año, como las del mes de Diciembre. Esta es la razón por la cual accederá a su credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con el que comprará productos de belleza, para provisionarse de insumos que requiere,  para ofrecer un buen servicio y también comprará mercancías variadas, como productos de bisutería y accesorios femeninos,  que son los productos de mas salida,  en la temporada mas alta que tiene su negocio.
texts.en:
Sandra, age 33, lives with her spouse and two children, ages 2 and 8. They live in the Soledad municipality, home of the butifarras (specialty sausages). Soledad is located 15 minutes from Barranquilla. 
Sandra works to improve her clients' personal and professional images by offering haircuts, massages, hairstyling, manicures and pedicures, and hair treatments. She learned to do this so that she could open her own business and generate an important income for her family. She has been doing this for six years in a space that she outfitted herself in her own home. Her first customers were her neighbours, family and close friends. They still go to her, and refer more clients her way every day. Now, her business' potential to grow has exceeded what she is able to do on her own; her clientele is growing every day, so Sandra's need for working capital is becoming more and more evident. The money that she currently has is not enough to meet her customer demand, especially now that the most important holiday season is coming up: December. For this reason, she has turned to a Kiva loan. This is her first loan with the Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo. With this loan, she will purchase beauty products in order to stock up on the tools that she needs. This will allow her to offer a good service. She will also buy varied merchandise, such as costume jewellery and women's accessories; these are her most popular products. This is her business' busiest season.

loans.use: to buy beauty products in order to stock up on the products that she needs in order to provide a good service. She will also buy varied merchandise, such as costume jewellery and women's accessories.

loans.name: Duoc

texts.en:
Mrs Duoc is taking this loan out for her daughter, student Mai.  Hoping to be an accountant in the future, Mai has gained a place at Hanoi National College for Economy and Technology.  Her tuition lasts for three years and will end in 2014.  Studying this profession, she will eventually work for a commercial company and earn a good salary. 

To make her dream come true, Mai is studying very hard and trying to overcome difficulties as much as she can to gain good results.  She wants to borrow a loan of 14,580,000 Vietnam dong to pay for tuition fees, books and other supplies.

loans.use: to pay for tuition fees, books and other supplies.

loans.name: Chay

texts.en:
Mrs. Chay is a 34-year-old married woman who has been residing in Reussey Keo commune. She is engaged in an agricultural business, cultivating rice crops, from which she is able to generate approximately $1.00 per day. She has 3 children who work as sewing staff to help support the family. 

Chay wants to help to her children who go to work everyday by taking a vehicle-taxi service. This causes them to have higher expenses. Consequently, she is asking for a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorcycle. The motorcycle will provide a good service for commuting her children to their workplace. Chay is very happy and grateful. She tells us that she won’t give a late payment to our lenders as it is her third loan.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle.

loans.name: John Onyango

texts.en:
John  has been renting a motorcycle for taxi work for three years. He  is married with two children and lives in a heavily populated suburb of Kisumu  City. John has committed to   provide transport to CHWs targeting heavily populated slum providing peer support to youth groups Owning his own bike makes him feel motivated to work for himself and his community.

By owning his own bike, John will also be able to provide for his family and support the community as well, John belongs to a motorcycle taxi association and hopes to encourage many more members to join in supporting the CHW work in heavily populated areas of Kisumu City

loans.use: To buy a Motorcycle for Community Health Work and Livelihoods

loans.name: Robert

texts.en: Robert is 35 years old with three children living in Bundibugyo, Uganda. His major business is coffee buying. He also has a cocoa garden from which he harvests his cocoa, sells it and gets additional income. He started the business with the aim of improving his standard of living. He wants to educate his children to a higher level and he is working hard amidst the challenge of competition in the business environment that may not favor him. Robert intends to use the loan to buy more coffee and cocoa to sell.

loans.use: To buy more coffee and cocoa to sell.

loans.name: Las Violentas Group

texts.es: El grupo solidario Las Violentas ha mostrado ser un grupo organizado, exitoso  responsable  con los pagos de sus créditos anteriores, el grupo lo coordina  Fátima de 35 años de edad, casada y madre de dos hijos de  13 y 9 años. Ella se dedica desde hace quince años a la venta de ropa y cosméticos  en su domicilio, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo quien le ayuda a entregar los productos y vender. Solicita por tercer ciclo el financiamiento en la institución porque desea expandir su negocio por medio de la inversión de más productos como camisas, pantalones, chores y faldas, con el crédito anterior logro terminar de pagar una moto. La segunda socia es María de 29 años de edad, se dedica a la venta de ropa y la tercer socia es Leiken de 24 años, quien se dedica a la venta de productos perecederos.

loans.use: para la compra de camisas, pantalones, chores y faldas

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand my brick business. I will hire a brick making machine for 3 weeks to make 5,000 bricks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The loan will be invested in the maintenance and repair of his turning lathe and other machines. Moreover, he will invest the rest of the loan to purchase materials and improve his shop.

loans.name: Chandra Laxmi

texts.en:
Mrs. Chandra Laxmi S., 40 years old, is a tailor in the town of Volakhel in Patan.  She opened her tailoring shop 4 years ago. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies dresses and school uniforms for both boys and girls. She prefers to make popular dresses like Kurta Sulwar, Blouse, Ladies long dress, Makhshi, and others. 
Before starting her own business, Mrs S. took a 6 month training course in tailoring when she was younger.
She plans to use the loan to buy raw materials for her tailoring work. She wants to add to her family's income and support her children's education.
Her husband's name is Bidya Ratna S. and he makes brass religious statues. She has two daughters, 17 and 11 years old. The youngest daughter is in grade 7 and the oldest daughter just took the SLC (School Leaving Certificate) exam this year. The oldest daughter also helps her mother in her shop.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for tailoring shop

loans.name: Im

texts.en: Mrs. Im S. is a 50 year old housewife. She has 4 children, one of which is a student. The other three are garment workers. Her husband (pictured here) earns $5 a day charging batteries for vehicles. Their business would greatly improve if they had this loan so that they could buy a new battery charger. They have high hopes for expansion of the business in the future.

loans.use: To buy a new battery charging machine

loans.name: Litia

texts.en: Litia is a happily married mother of six. She supports her husband by working on their taro plantation six days a week. She rarely asks her family living overseas for a financial support because she makes $300-$400 a month by selling 3-4 bags of taro at the market twice a week. She is applying for this new loan from SPBD in order to keep her children in school and to extend her four-acre taro plantation.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, weed killers, a spade and other supplies for her taro plantation

loans.name: Julia Miriam

texts.es:
Julia Miriam is receiver of microcredit who has established with her own money the sale of homemade food, and who has offered her clients the delicious Sopa de Res or Meat Soup, rice, Meat prepared in special ways, plaintains and fried plaintains both with cheese, tortillas, etc.

She has worked 34 years in this business, and she comments that she began selling bean soup in her house as a way to receive extra income from other sources because her husband was unemployed. Due to the great demand for her product she has established herself successfully in the Mercado Central de León to offer the workers of this area a place to eat healthy food close to work.

She has been using these systems of credit for a year and six months, and her own words are:

"To work with credits has helped me, it has allowed my family and I to continue forward in this business. I continue with my clients while attracting new ones who enjoy typical nicaraguan food that I prepare for them. My dream is to continue forward and to accumulate earnings to buy my own space to establish a restaurant. Julia Miriam es una microempresaria que ha establecido con dinero propio la venta de comidería, comida preparada en casa, ofrece a sus clientes la riquísima Sopa de Res, arroz, Carne en sus diferentes maneras de preparar, maduro frito con queso (platanos fritos con queso), tortillas, etc.

Tiene aproximadamente 34 años de laborar en este negocio, ella nos comenta que inició vendiendo sopa de frijoles en su casa como una manera de buscar otros ingresos ya que su esposo habia quedado desempleado. Debido a la gran demanda que tiene su producto y a petición de los cliientes, ella se ha establecido en el Mercado Central de León para ofrecer a los trabajadores de esta zona un lugar donde comer sanamente y cerca de sus trabajos.

Trabaja con los sistemas de crédito desde hace un año y seis meses, sus palabras textuales son las siguientes:

"Trabajar con créditos me ha ayudado, nos ha permitido a mi y a la familia a salir adelante con este negocio, sigo manteniendo mi clientela y ganando clientes nuevos que gustan de la comida típica nicaragüense que yo les preparo, mi deseo es seguir adelante y lograr acumular mas ganancias para comprar mi propio módulo y llegar a tener un restaurante".

loans.use:
To purchase supplies like rice, oil, beans, beef, chicken, etc. to prepare food to sell in her business.

Compra de Insumos como Arro, Aceite, Frijoles, carne de res, Pollo, etc. para preparar la comida que ofrece en el negocio.

loans.name: Amélé

texts.fr:
Married and the mother of 4 children, Mrs. Amélé S. was born in 1982. Today, she lives in Attitogon in her husband's home. Her daily work is selling shoes (sandals). Ready to help pay for the household expenses through her work in her sales, Amélé is applying for a loan of $200 to help expand her business, especially in this Holiday season. This will help her to purchase more sandals and add full foot covering shoes as well. The earnings from this enterprise will allow her to support the needs of her family, above all those of her children and their schooling, which will help them to succeed in life.

Translated from French by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Mariée et mère de quatre (4) enfants, Madame S. Amélé est née en 1982. Actuellement elle vit à Attitogon au foyer de son mari. La vente des chaussures (sandales) reste son activité quotidienne. Prête à contribuer aux dépenses du ménage à partir des revenus de son commerce, Amélé sollicite un financement de $200 pour augmenter la taille de son activité surtout en cette période de fêtes. Ceci lui permettra d’acheter plus de sandales et y ajouter des chaussures. Les bénéfices de son activité lui permettront de bien subvenir aux besoins de sa famille surtout ses enfants en scolarité afin de parvenir à leur épanouissement.

loans.use: Purchase and sales of shoes.

loans.name: Acholi F Group

texts.en:
Carol is 32 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a teacher. She has a beauty salon business. Carol wants her children to become teachers like their father. With the extra business profits, she wants to buy a piece of land. Rosemary and E. both have stone quarrying businesses and want to use the loan to expand them. Annet sells charcoal and wants to purchase more charcoal to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more salon equipment.

loans.name: Samina  Sehar's Group

texts.en:
My name Samina Sehar A. and I have lived all my life in Multan, a mid-sized city in Pakistan. I own a three-room house here in Multan where I live with my husband and four children: two girls and two boys. Two of my children are older than 15 and two are still quite young. I have run a boutique for many years, and also create embroidered outfits, which my brother sells in the big city of Karachi, Pakistan. For every dress I make, I earn a profit of about $2 to $3. I want to expand my business so that I can improve my income and repair my house.

I lead a loan group whose members are: Hafeezan M., who will use the loan to buy her son a rickshaw. Rehmat B. sells paper and Hajra B. sells cloth and paper; both need new items to sell. All of these women are mutually responsible for the loan; if one does not pay, the others will pay for her.

loans.use: To expand four small businesses

loans.name: Lorena

texts.es:
Lorena R. is married and has a ten year-old son. Her story begins 16 years ago, when she began, along with a brother-in-law, to use clearance sales. Lorena and her brother-in-law began purchasing paintings from Ciudad Juárez, Chihuahua, Mexico, in order to make and sell frames. At that time Lorena’s husband was working for a trucking company that subsequently closed. He became unemployed, and they thus had to look for another way to pay for family expenses. They decided to open a business selling frames and mirrors.

Lorena needs to expand her business but she does not have the necessary capital. She is looking for a loan of $475 US that will be repaid in 6 months.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

Lorena R. es casada y tiene un hijo de 10 años su historia inicia hace 16 años, empezó con un cuñado utilizando la liquidación, de este empezaron trayendo pinturas de Cd. Juárez, Chihuahua, para hacer y vender marcos. En ese entonces su esposo trabajaba en una línea de camiones la cual cerraron originando que lo desocuparan, fue así que tuvieron que buscar la manera de costear los gastos familiares y decidieron abrir un negocio de venta de marcos y espejos.

Ante la necesidad de ampliar el negocio pero no contando con el capital suficiente es que buscan un apoyo económico por US $475 que liquidaran en 6 meses.

loans.use: To remodel the business

loans.name: Walayat's Group

texts.en: I am Walayat M. from Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. I am married and have six kids: four boys and two girls. I could not educate any of my kids due to very poor economic conditions a few years ago. My husband is a retired officer and one of my sons manufactures shoes. This is the busy season and therefore my son wants to manufacture shoes in a larger quantity.  However, he lacks the required finances. As a group of women, we are requesting a loan.  The group includes: Suriya R. (who needs the loan to buy a bull cart), Farzana Z. (her husband manufactures shoe buckles), Shahnaz A. (who will use the loan to fix her family’s rickshaw) and Suriya B. (who wants to buy a lathe (a machine used to turn objects)).  All of us are in need of this loan and your help can bring prominent change in our lives.

loans.use: to manufacture shoes in bulk

loans.name: Yuli

texts.id:
Yuli A. is a mother of one. She and her husband is now expecting for their 2nd child. They rent a piece of land and buit a semi-permanent house on it.

Yuli is in the business of making and selling cookies. She starts her day at 03.00 am everyday as she has to cook the cookies early in the morning. In the morning she then brings her cookies to the nearby market to be sold in there.

She uses the proceed from her business to help paying her family's daily necessities and also to be saved for the delivery of her 2nd child. She is hoping to be able to expand her business with this loan money.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva volunteer.

Saat ini klien tinggal di Jl.Laksamana Denpasar bersama suami dan anaknya. Mereka mengontrak tanah dan membangun rumah semi permanen diatasnya. Keadaan keluarganya sehat dan saat ini dia sedang mengandung anak kedua. Usaha yang sedang dijalani oleh Yuli A. saat ini adalah sebagai penjual kue. Ada berbagai macam kue yang dijualnya. Kegiatannya setiap hari adalah mulai jam 03.00 dinihari dia sudah harus bangun untuk membuat kue. Pada pagi harinya dia membawa kue yang sudah dibuatnya ke pasar terdekat. Tempatnya tidak begitu jauh dari rumahnya, cukup dengan berjalan kaki saja. Keuntungan yang didapat selain untuk memenuhi kebutuhan rumah tangga, juga rencananya mau ditabung sebagi persiapan buat kelahiran anaknya. Yuli A. sangat mengharapkan diberi bantuan modal sehingga usahanya lebih berkembang.

loans.use: To add working capital (Menambah Modal Usaha)

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 26-year-old Mariam M..  She is married, and has two children aged 1 and 12. She has two dependents, who live with her because they are orphans. In 2007, Mariam established her phone accessories business. She opens her business 6 days a week, and 8 hours a day. Despite being a ‘developing’ country (forgive the label, there remains no consensus on an acceptable definition), it is amazing how many people have mobile phones in Tanzania and in Africa in general. Not just professionals, but grandmas in villages, school kids, street sellers. It can probably be attributed to a number of factors, led by the fact that it is the only form of phone communication available to most people, because there are few landlines, and mobile phones are relatively cheap  here.  The mobile phone business is a very good business. Mariam requests a loan to purchase additional stock, such as batteries, cases, and chargers. In the future, Mariam plans to increase the quantity and range of her stock. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of phone accessories ( batteries, cases and chargers)

loans.name: Yessica

texts.es:
Yessica is a member of the Lilies II Communal Bank, located in Jr. Comandante Barrera 276 in the Calleria District in the Ucayali area of Peru. She is 26 years old and has one son; her husband is a mechanic. With the first loan received from Manuela Ramos in the amount of S/. 300, she started a business selling local fruits. She wants to continue in this line of work, selling fruits and beverages of the region (aguaje, hungurahui, maní and other refreshments).

With the requested loan of S/ 1,200, which is to be repaid in 5 months, she will buy sacks of aguaje fruit, hungurahui fruit, trays and glasses. Additionally, she will make modifications in her sales module and will pay for a Municipal license.

Yessica is very grateful to the Manuela Ramos Bank for their support. She realizes that implementing her own business will allow her to take care of her own as well as her family's needs.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva vounteer.

La señora Yessica pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Azucenas II, ubicado en el Jr. Comandante Barrera 276, Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 26 años y tiene un hijo y su esposo es Mecánico, Sonia con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 implemento su negocio en venta de frutas regionales. En la actualidad sigue con el negocio de venta de frutas y bebidas regionales (aguaje hungurahui, maní y refrescos).

Con este préstamo recibido de S/ 1,200 el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará varios sacos de aguajes, hungurahui, bandejas, vasos. Además hará arreglos en su módulo de venta y pagará el permiso Municipal.

Yessica está muy agradecida con el Banco Manuela Ramos por el apoyo que le brinda y además se siente realizada dado que puede atender algunas necesidades propias de ella así como de su familia, por ello el deseo de seguir implementado su negocio.

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of fruits (aguaje, hungurahui) and utensils. Payment of municipal license.

loans.name: Naomi N.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 39-year-old Naomi Adamu. She is married and has four children between the ages of three and 18. In 2007, Naomi established her crops-selling business. Working five days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about 260 USD every month from this business. She is assisted by her husband. Naomi requires a loan in order to purchase more crops in bulk. In the future, Naomi plans to expand and establish another business. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk

loans.name: Thi Bich Hang's Group

texts.vi:
Chị C. Thị Bích Hằng 30 tuổi, mã số 06030034 chị và cả nhóm lần đầu tiên tham gia vay vốn của SEDA. Tháy các chị em phụ nữ trong thôn vay vốn chị cũng tìm hiểu cách thức vay trả. Sau khi được cán bộ tín dụng tư vấn chị rất thích tham gia vì được tiết kiệm trả dần.Chị đăng ký tham gia vay 3.186.000đ về lấy thêm cám để bán cho các hộ chăn nuôi trong làng.Chị có 2 con đang đi học, trồng chị cũng giúp chị nhiều trong công việc buôn bán. Trong nhóm chị còn có 4 thanh viên nưã cung tham gia vay vốn

.
  • Chị Lưu Thị Bắc 35 tuổi, mã số 06030035 vay 3.186.000đ trả trong 6 tháng về mua cám chăn nuôi gà đẻ
  • Chị Đinh Thị Tập 58 tuổi mã số 06030036 vay 3186.000đ để mua lợn giống
  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Vân 33 tuổi mã số 06030037 vay 3186.000đ mua ngô nổ bỏng
  • Anh Kiều Văn dũng 24 tuổi mã số 06030038 vay 3186.000gg mua gà để nuôi
texts.en:
Ms. C. Thị Bích Hằng, 30 years old, no 06030034. Her group is borrowing for the first time from the SEDA fund. All the housewives in the group worked together to find ideas to invest and pay back the loans̉. She is very eager to adhere to be able to save and repay gradually. She is asking for a loan of 3.186.000đ to buy animal feed and resell at the market to the village farmers. She has 2 school-age children, who also help her out when there is a lot of sales activity. There are 4 other Fund participants in her group

.
  • Ms. Lưu Thị Bắc, 35 years, no 06030035, borrowing 3.186.000đ over 6 months to buy chicken feed
  • Ms. Đinh Thị Tập, 58 years, no 06030036, borrowing 3.186.000đ to buy pigs
  • Ms. Nguyễn Thị Vân, 33 years, no 06030037, borrowing 3.186.000đ to buy corn for use as animal feed
  • Mr. Kiều Văn, 24 years, no 06030038, borrowing 3.186.000đ to buy chicken to raise

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Minh Bui, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying animal feed

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en: Eugenia F. R. is a member of community bank, El Roble, which means "oak tree." She lives in Ayacucho with her partner and three children, 21, 17 & 15. She sells and sews clothing including traditional slips worn under women's skirts. She also sells cheese at the local fairs on Sundays. She will invest her loan of $1500 into the purchase of thread, materials, lace, needles and cheese. She is saving to purchase a laptop and dreams of being able to send her children to school to become professionals.

loans.use: Eugenia would like to purchase thread, materials, lace and needles for her sewing business.

loans.name: Carnen Rosa

texts.es:
La señora Carmen Rosa, socia del BC Mujeres Activas, vive en la Región San Martín, provincia y distrito de Bellavista. Tiene 46 años de edad, es madre de 9 hijos y vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos que aún dependen de ella. 

Se dedica a la venta anticuchos de carne de pollo asados al carbón y Juanes. Desarrolla el negocio en el Jr, Huallaga C-03, es una de las calles céntricas de la ciudad. Se inició con un primer préstamo de Manuela Ramos con el cual compró una parrilla y empezó a vender.  

Con este crédito de S/.1,700, el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará los insumos para la preparación de los alimentos como, arroz, azúcar, carnes de res, pollo y cerdo en kilos, también cecina y chorizo que le permitirá variar los platos que ofertará a sus clientes y atenderá la petición de sus clientes, además desea comprar una refrigeradora que le hace mucha falta para su negocio. 

Carmen Rosa manifiesta que Manuela Ramos es un apoyo para ella y para su familia, así como para las demás mujeres que quieren salir adelante. Más adelante piensa buscar un local para dar una mejor atención a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mrs. Carmen Rosa is a member of the communal bank Mujeres Activas. She lives in the region of San Martín, in the Bellavista province. She is 46 years old, a mother of 9 children and lives with her husband and three children who are still dependent upon her. She sells beef and chicken kebabs made on the grill in addition to Juanes. She develops her business in the Jr, Huallaga C-03- it is one of the central streets in the city. She started with her first loan from Manuela Ramos with which she bought a grill and started selling. With this loan of 1,700 soles, which she plans to pay back in 6 months, she will purchase ingredients to prepare foods, such as rice, sugar, beef, chicken and pork in kilos, jerky, and sausage. These items will help her vary the dishes she prepares for her customers, and will be able to make custom dishes. In addition, she would like to purchase a refrigerator which she needs for her business. Carmen Rosa says that Manuela Ramos is a support to her and her family, much like it is to other women who want to suceed. In the future, she would like to find a shop to better serve her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Natalie Kane, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, sugar, beef, chicken, jerky, sausage

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn married at an early age of 18, but she did not take this as a reason to be discouraged and to regret the life she has now. Her husband, Orlan, is a former vegetable vendor, but is now plants eggplants in their backyard, where Marilyn gets most of her vegetables. They are blessed with three children and they need to be more patient and industrious to support their family’s growing needs. They live in the village of Malamag West, where people are hardworking and well-discipline. Planting native and yellow corn and different vegetables are the major sources of income in the area.

Marilyn sells different kinds of vegetables in their village, and she walks from house to house selling the harvested vegetables to her regular customers. The nature of her business taught Marilyn to be confident in dealing with other people. She uses her daily net income of Php100 to meet their immediate needs. It is a good thing that Marilyn knows how to budget well, because otherwise, her daily income would not be enough for their food, the children’s allowances, and other needs. 

Marilyn is now contemplating about expanding her business. She is asking for a loan of Php3, 000 to be able to  buy more vegetables, meat, eggs and dried fish.

According to Marilyn, she wants to help her husband to provide for their needs and to send their children to school.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Flor De Vida Group

texts.es:
La asociación denominada “Flor de vida” pertenece a la familia de  Pro-Mujer hace más de cuatro años , esta  se encuentra en la zona de villa Adela, de la ciudad de El Alto, a la fecha  cuenta con 15 miembros y han demostrado ser un grupo organizado en cuanto a sus cuotas de crédito.
Dentro el grupo la mayoría tienen hijos, casi todos en edad escolar, intentan ofrecer a sus hijos además de una  educación básica, estudios universitarios para así asegurarles un mejor futuro. 
Además de la artesanía en ropa, actividad a la que se dedica Zenobia, la mayor parte de la asociación de dedica al comercio en general,  venden verduras en el mercado central de la Ceja de El Alto, otras de las socias son vivanderas. Todas necesitan mayor capital para ampliar sus negocios, considerando que esta época del año aumenta su clientela.
texts.en:
The “Flor de Vida” association (‘Flower of Life’) has been a part of the Pro-Mujer family for more than 4 years. It is located in the Villa Adela region of El Alto city and currently has 15 members, who have proved themselves very organized in regards to their timely loan payments. The majority of the group members have children, most of school age, and they try to provide both basic and higher education opportunities to their children for a better future. Besides Zenobia’s work making handicrafts and artisanal clothing, the other members have different small businesses, selling vegetables in the Ceja de El Alto central market or working as street vendors. All need more capital to expand their businesses, especially since they have more customers during this time of year.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital to expand business

loans.name: Norma

texts.es:
La señora Norma H. y su esposo el señor Carlos Javier Salazar, tiene dos hijos en edad escolar a los cuales desean darles lo mejor. 
 A su vivienda le está haciendo falta una losa de concreto en el patio ya que cuando están las lluvias se inunda y los niños no pueden salir a jugar. 
Está solicitando un préstamo para poder realizar la mejora lo más pronto posible, planea pagar con los ingresos de su trabajo.
texts.en:
Mrs. Norma H. and her husband, Mr. Carlos Javier Salazar, have two school-age children. They would like to give them their best.

Their house needs concrete floor slabs on the patio since it floods when it rains and the children can't go out to play.

She is applying for a loan in order to make the improvements as soon as possible. She plans to pay with income from her job.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Concrete floor slabs for patio

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Kong S. is 53 years old and lives with his wife in Bati district, Takeo province. He is a taxi driver and makes US$5 of profit per day. His wife sells various kinds of vegetables at Phnom Penh market and earns approximately US$40 in revenue every day. Kong and his wife have four children; two are construction workers and one is in school. This couple has requested a loan to purchase vegetables to sell at the Phnom Penh market.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Tsolmonbaatar

texts.en: Tsolmonbaatar P. lives with his wife and two children in Tsetserleg city, located in the Arhangay province. His children both go to kindergarten. Although his family has its own piece of land, they live in their mother's home because of its close access to the local market. Together with his wife, Tsolmonbaatar sells second hand clothing and and also transports passengers from Tsetserleg city to Ulaanbaatar, the capital. In July 2008, Tsolmonbaatar and his wife bought a freight train cargo container for 3,000,000 tugrig ($1 USD=1,570 tugrig) and converted it into a bicycle repair shop. Their daily gross income is 15,000-25,000 tugrig and the profit ranges between 7,000-15,000 tugrig a day.  They have taken two loans from XacBank (Kiva's microfinance partner in Mongolia) and paid back both loans on time.  Tsolmonbaatar and his wife put a lot of heart into their business and they complement each other in this family activity.  In the near future, they hope to have their own piece of land located close to the local market. They also hope to build a larger repair shop.  The loan will be used to purchase repair accessories and welding materials.

loans.use: To purchase repair accessories and welding materials

loans.name: Opetela

texts.en: Opetela F., 55, is married with 7 children.  She is just starting a business as a baker. She sells to the general public 7 days per week, and has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (about 250 USD).  SPBD loans are Opetela’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: sack of flour, sack of sugar, barrow of oil, gas stove, pots

loans.name: Comunidad Unida - Group 1

texts.en:
Maritza R. represents this group of five micro entrepreneurs. They live in an area called Brisas del Ozama, by the Ozama River shore. The river divides Santo Domingo in two halves. Maritza and her friends live on the eastern side. Maritza has 5 children, ages 24, 22, 19, 18 and 16. Only the two youngest ones still live with her.

Maritza mostly sells children's clothing, which she buys in bundles (she told us there are tons of children in her area). However, with this loan she will buy a bundle that includes sheets and curtains (at her clientele's request) and a bundle of jeans. There are many men who do handwork that wear jeans everyday. They have asked her to buy men's jeans, so they can buy them from her. Her male clients say she sells good clothing at a fair price. One of the challenges Maritza faces as a businesswoman is to recognize trustworthy customers. ''You might encounter unreliable people that won't pay you."

Maritza would like to set up all her merchandise at a store and add more variety to her sales. For example, she might like to add shoes to her merchandise in the near future. On behalf of this group of entrepreneurs, we would like to thank you for supporting this Kiva loan!

loans.use: Purchase additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Afia

texts.en:
Afia O. is divorced and has two kids. She lives with her family at Akim Wenchi in the eastern region of Ghana. She is 31 years old.

For the past six years, Afia has run a clothing shop where she sells jeans, blouses, skirts, women's slippers, other clothes, and dressing bags. She takes her stock of goods from importers at Accra. Afia works very hard to provide a quality education for her children. Afia is constrained by funds to run the business. She needs a loan to inject more working capital into her business to scale up business progress. She believes the loan will help her to have the resources to purchase good quality goods in large quantities to upgrade her inventory. She says she would be grateful for that assistance. She belongs to a village bank called Nkwa Nsuo, which literary means living waters.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell

loans.name: Adelfa

texts.en: Adelfa S. is from Tuburan, Cagayan De Oro City. She is 48 years old and is a widow with three children. She supports her family through traditional gold mining. She is also engaged in food-processing business wherein she uses her skill to make pan cakes and rice cakes and then peddles it to her neighboring village. She uses her income to support the educational expenses of her children, to improve her existing business and to buy daily necessities for consumption. She intends to expand her business and hence is applying for a loan of PHP 5,000 payable in five months.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients for her food processing business

location.town: Tuburan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Luz Pilar

texts.es:
La señora Luz Pilar, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Violetas II”, vive en el Jr. Bolognesi Nº 524, Distrito de Nueva Cajamarca, Provincia Rioja Departamento de San Martín. Es conviviente, tiene 30 años, 03 hijos, 2 de ellas estudian en la escuela primaria  y  la última educación inicial.

Su espíritu juvenil y la necesidad de ayudar en el ingreso económico del hogar le motivo a iniciarse en el negocio y no vio la mejor manera de hacerlo con el primer préstamo que le otorgaron de S/. 300.00,  con esto mandó a confeccionar una maleta de madera  y en ella ofrecer las golosinas que tenia proyectado vender a sus clientes que serian los alumnos y profesores de un centro educativo que se ubica muy cerca de su casa., es así como se inicia y hoy continua con la misma actividad, diariamente tiene muy buenas ventas por lo que se siente muy contenta, por eso trabaja en doble turno por la mañana en un centro educativo y por la tarde en otro. 

Con el préstamo de S/. 800.00, lo invertirá comprando golosinas como: chocolates sublimes, cañonazo; chupetines, chicles y galletas y caramelos en diferentes sabores y marcas; así satisfacer a sus clientes, parte del dinero también lo invirtió comprando pequeños juguetes que también son  pedidos de sus pequeños clientes.

Se siente muy satisfecha con el trabajo que realiza, pese que es un trabajo que le demanda bastante tiempo ,  cree que vale el sacrificio para cumplir sus sueños y metas que tiene trazado en su vida como son el de tener su propia casa.
texts.en:
Ms. Luz Pilar is a member of the “Las Violetas II” Microfinance Institute. She is a 30-year-old married mother of 3 children, 2 of whom are in elementary school while the other is in preschool.

Her youthful spirit and her need to help with the household income motivated her to start her own business, and what better way to do it than with her first 300.00 PEN loan. With this money, she had a wooden case made so that she can use it to sell candy to her customers—the students and teachers of an educational center near her home. Thus, she started her business, which she is still running today. Everyday, sales are good, which makes her happy. For that reason, she works double shifts—in the morning at one educational center, and in the evening at another.

She will invest this 800.00 PEN loan in purchasing sweets, such as: Sublime white chocolate, Cañonazo chocolate crispy wafers, lollipops, bubble gum, cookies, and candies of different brands and flavors so that she can keep her customers satisfied. She will also invest some of the money in purchasing small toys that her young customers ordered.

She feels very satisfied with her work, even though it takes up a lot of her time. She thinks it is worth the sacrifice because she can realize her dreams and reach her lifetime goal of getting her own house.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase candy to increase inventory

loans.name: United Club 5 Group

texts.en:
Wahr is a 32-year-old man who was only able to get to 10th grade in school.  Together with his wife, he now has 3 children: one who is 6, one who is 5, and the baby who is 1.  His older children are in a local private school.   

 Wahr has a business renting out wheelbarrows for people to use to sell their goods.  In Liberia, it is very common for people to fill a wheelbarrow with goods and walk around trying to sell them.  The types of goods you might find in the wheelbarrow are fruits, hair pieces, sweets, spices, and other small things.  

  Renting a wheelbarrow from Wahr costs 200 LD per day – and he has 30 “wheels” that he rents each day.  He has been running this business for 4 years, and he is always trying to increase the number of “wheels” he has for rent.  With the loan he is requesting now he will be able to purchase new “wheels!”  He says the price changes often so he is not sure how many yet!

loans.use: New Wheelbarrows to rent out

loans.name: Merilyn

texts.en: Merilyn M. is from the village of Butuay, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 51 years old, married, and has two adult children. Merilyn owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling clothing and shoes in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-three years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Merilyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Merilyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her fourth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: 05-Đông Sơn Group

texts.en:
"Liên Lê Thị (48) is a 46 year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Liên is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 05-Đông Sơn (10.13.05).

Liên is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Liên owns and operates a business making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of food products in the local community. Liên has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1.500.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2005, Liên joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liên has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3.079.800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. She is now requesting a new loan of 6.000.000 VND which will also be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 7th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Liên plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1. T. Thị Thu (44) is a 59-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector, running a general store.

2. Đỗ Thị Tân (131) is a 49-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector, making and selling food.

3. N. Thị Vân (152) is a 28-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector, making and selling food.

4. Trịnh Thị Thu (213) is a 42-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the services sector, operating a tailoring business.

5. Lê Thị Nương (42) is a 40-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector, making and selling food.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Liên Lê Thị (48) là 46 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá. Liên là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 05-Đông Sơn (10.13.05).

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán các loại thực phẩm khác nhau trong cộng đồng địa phương. Liên thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 10 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Liên kiếm được khoảng 1.500.000 VND. Vào 2005, Liên đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Liên đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3.079.800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND.

Khoản vay sẽ là 7th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:

1. T. Thị Thu (44) là 59 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa.

2. Đỗ Thị Tân (131) là 49 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.

3. N. Thị Vân (152) là 28 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.

4. Trịnh Thị Thu (213) là 42 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh may mặc.

5. Lê Thị Nương (42) là 40 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.

Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."

loans.use: to invest in expanding their businesses

loans.name: Simiatu

texts.en: Simiatu is 65 years old and married with six children. She sells motorcycle parts and is requesting a loan amount of N60,000 to purchase additional motorcycle parts to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional motorcycle parts to sell

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Prudencio S. 49 years old, find a good and a helpful partner in life after marrying Teresita S. 43 years old. Teresita helps her husband in making income for their family. Her husband is a farmer so the main source of their income comes from farming, but because they do not own the rice field they’ll not getting all the revenue from the farming of rice, they’ll only getting percentage on it. So Teresita think of another business aside from that. As of now, she has a variety store that sell different goods that needed by the people living nearby houses and also a store that sell batchoy, a noodle soup that mostly Filipino eat, both this business contributes in their income. This business comes from the loan that she loan in ASHI.

Now, Teresita wants again to help her husband in growing the business that he manages, which is the farming rice business. She will have a loan again to Kiva field partner, Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) for buying fertilizers and other things that are needed in making the business of her husband to grow so that someday they will have their own rice field to cultivate.

Also Teresita is a loving mother to their only son Jerry who is now 26 years old. She is hoping that he will give him a better life and a happy family.

loans.use: Will be used to finance her rice farming business

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria hails from beautiful Teresa, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is a mother to three and all are already of legal age. She is 65 years old already, but strong and determined to have her own source of income.
She joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Phillipines. Since she is already old, she wants a business that fits her capacity. She needs capital to continue her rug-making business. She makes the rugs and sells them to businessmen who send them to market.
Now on her fifth loan, she proposes a loan of 25,000 pesos as additional capital for her rug-making business. She will use the loan to pay for assorted cloths used as raw materials, threads and needles.
She is very thankful that KIVA people through ASHI are able to share in the poverty alleviation program.

loans.use: To buy cloth, thread and needles.

loans.name: Hamida Row Havza Group

texts.en:
Hamida Row Havza is the group leader of Hamida Row Havza group. There are seven members in this group. They want to take a loan for expanding their business and making them larger.

Hamida wants to take a loan for the business of tailoring. Rabi wants to take a loan for the business of flower making. Row Havza wants to take a loan for her husband who has car parts shop. Nargis wants to take a loan for the business of bead working.

Rakia wants to take a loan for the business of quilt making. Deba wants to take a loan for the business of embroidery. Maliha wants to receive a loan for the business of carpet weaving. They all thank AFS and Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For business progress

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
61-year-old Corazon P. recently joined the KIVA field partner ASHI in the Philippines to be able to access a loan. Corazon's husband is a farmer.
With the  loan that she is requesting, she can finance the starting of a business and have her own source of income. With this business she hopes to make enough profits to allow her only child to attend college, as well as pay for some of their their other personal needs. Corazon is hopeful that through this loan, through ASHI and KIVA, her family’s poor lifestyle will be improved and her child to have a brighter future.

loans.use: To be used to purchase a cow to raise and sell

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia C. is from the village of Inasagan, Aurora, Zamboanga del sur. She is 48 years old and married with five school-aged children. To make a living, Lilia owns and operates a business buying and selling dry cloth in the local community. Lilia has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately $112 a month from these activities.

In 2007, Lilia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Lilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Lilia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional new items for sell. This will be her 5th loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional new items to sell

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma B. is from the village of Yahong, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 41 years old. Wilma is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Wilma owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Wilma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Wilma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Wilma is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Wilma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for her children.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Tawana's Group

texts.en:
Towana C. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God First. She is 43 years old and a widow with seven children between the ages of 6 and 27. She also cares for two brothers. She is an illiterate due to lack of financial support. Towana and her family live in the Melekie community close to Gbarnga city, the capital of Bong county, Liberia.

Her business is the sale of general goods. She buys goods wholesale and sells retail to residents of her community. Towana has been running this business for ten years, and hopes to upgrade her business to a shop.

The transportation of goods to her business site is a difficulty for Towana, because the road conditions are very bad. Because of that, drivers charge huge amounts to take goods from one location to another.

Towana has always had good relationships with her customers in order to encourage them to continue to patronize her business.

She needs this loan to purchase more new goods to increase sales. She dreams of giving her children a better education.

loans.use: to purchase more new goods to improve sales.

loans.name: Bolaji

texts.en:
Bolaji is 42 years old and married. She has three children, the eldest of whom is 15 years old. Her husband sells spare parts for motors to support their family. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. She is a LAPO client.

Bolaji sells groceries at retail prices. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Elvia Maria

texts.es: Doña Elvia C. se dedica al negocio de una pulpería desde su casa de habitación. Ella actualmente es casada, tiene 56 años de edad, tiene dos hijos los cuales están trabajando por su cuenta. Ella dio inicio a este negocio desde hace 22 años, inicio primeramente vendiendo golosinas para los niños, y poco a poco fue reinvirtiendo en su negocio de tal manera que pudiera vender granos básicos, que es lo que más compra la gente. Ella afirma que su objetivo al establecer este negocio fue buscando una fuente alternativa para brindarle manutención a sus hijos, ya que para ese tiempo su esposo estaba sin trabajo por enfermedad, que era lo que mayormente le impedía realizar labores. Sin embargo, este negocio les ha servido muchísimo para salir adelante, ya que sus hijos pudieron prepararse en la universidad. Actualmente está solicitando un este crédito para la compra de mercancías principalmente desea invertir en los granos básicos, ya que para esta fecha es cuando puede aprovechar para vender más y de contado. La señora posee el sueño de tener un negocio grande en el mercado nuevo que brinde mayores ingresos a toda su familia.
texts.en:
Doña Elvia C. manages a grocery business out of her home. She is 56 years old, married, and has two children who work on their own. Elvia started her business 22 years ago selling sweets to children. She gradually reinvested into her business and added basic grains to her inventory, which is what most people buy from her. Elvia says the objective behind starting her business was to look for an alternative source of income to support her children. Her husband was out of work at the time due to illness, which prevented him from securing permanent employment. However, this business has helped her family get ahead and prepare her children for college.

At the moment, Elvia is requesting a loan to purchase merchandise, mostly basic grains which she is able to sell more of in exchange for cash payments. She dreams of opening a larger business at the new market so that she can generate more income for her entire family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Larch

texts.en: Larch K. is a 51-year-old and lives with two of her children and her husband in Takeo Province. She is a rice farmer and also raises animals to earn a living and is able to make about U.S. $1 of profit a day. Currently, her husband is a truck driver.  He usually transports cement and construction materials from building material supply shops to construction sites. Larch K. is asking for a loan of US$1,200 in order to help her husband purchase a work truck to transport construction materials. (Larch K. was not available for picture so her husband is picture instead)

loans.use: To purchase a truck.

loans.name: Agnes Njeri

texts.en:
Agnes is married to Stanley and they have three sons. Agnes is a green grocer, mainly selling fruit within an area called Ruaka on the outskirts of Nairobi. She has been in this business for a while. Her husband is also a businessman within the same town. 

Agnes was introduced to Kiva partner KADET by a friend and she has no previous credit history. This is her first loan and she is optimistic that it will help her boost her business especially after she increases her stock of fruits for sale.

Agnes desires to expand her business by opening a general shop so that she can accommodate other products to cater for most of the needs of her clients.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit.

loans.name: Saddam

texts.en:
Saddam S. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. He is 18 years old and single. To make a living, Saddam owns and operates a specialized retail store selling ready-to-wear clothing for different classes of ladies and also a selection of men's wear in the local community. Saddam has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns approximately $110 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Saddam joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Saddam has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Saddam is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be his 2nd loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue to continue to improve his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding his business

loans.name: Mylene's Group

texts.en:
Mylene P. is from the village of Bayabo East. She is 37 years old. Mylene is the group leader of an eight-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Mylene P..

Mylene is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Mylene owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Mylene has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Mylene joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mylene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. Mylene is requesting a new loan of 19,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Mylene from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Myrna's Group

texts.en:
Myrna Q. is from Calao East, Santiago, Isabela. She is thirty-nine years old. Myrna is the group leader of a ten-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Myrna Q.'s group.

Myrna is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Myrna owns and operates a business venture in the arts sector operating a handicraft business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling specialty handicrafts to tourists and local community members. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Myrna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts. Myrna is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts. This will be Myrna's third loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-nine branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts

loans.name: Pedrita

texts.en:
Pedrita owns a store and she sometimes sells at the elementary school in her barangay (village). She is 53 years old, married with three children. She has one child who is currently going to college. She and her husband work hard in order to sustain their child’s education. She also hopes to have a stable income.

In 2008, she joined CEVI hoping to gain access to its program. She says that its program is really helpful and she also likes the benefits she can get through insurance. She recently applied for a loan of 11,000 PHP, which she will use to buy stock, including boxes of Fern-C vitamins that she sells in her store.

loans.use: To buy additional inventory

loans.name: Alberto

texts.es: EL SR. ALBERTO Z. TIENE 40 AÑOS, ESTA CASADO HACE YA 8 AÑOS, TIENE 2 HIJOS PEQUEÑOS QUE VAN CURSANDO EL NIVEL PRIMARIO, SU ACTIVIDAD ECONOMICA ESTA REFERIDA A ALA AGRICULTURA, ESPECIFICAMENTE A LA PRODUCCION DE BANANO. AL SER QUIEN SOSTIENE SU HOGAR Y BUSCA OFRECERLES A SUS 2 PEUQEÑOS HIJOS UNA MEJOR CALIDAD DE VIDA PUESTO QUE EL TRABAJO AGRICOLA EN EL TROPICO ES MUY DURA, PRETENDE MEJORAR  E INCREMENTAR SU PRODUCCION A TRAVES DE ESTE CREDITO QUE LE PERMITIRA LOGRAR EN PARTE SUS OBJETIVOS, EL EMPEÑO Y EMPRENDIMIENTO QUE LE DA A SU ACTIVIDAD A LA CUAL LE DEDICA GRAN PARTE DEL DIA INTERCALANDO SU TIEMPO TAMBIEN CON EL CUIDADO DE SU NIÑOS A LA VEZ ENSEÑANDOLES DE SU TRABAJO PARA QUE MAS ADELANTE EN UN FUTURO, PUDAN SOSTENERSE ECONOMICAMENTE DE FORMA INDEPENDIENTE MEJORANDO SU CALIDAD DE VIDA.
texts.en:
Mr. Alberto Z. is 40 years old, has been married for eight years, and has two young children who are in primary school. He works in agriculture, specifically with banana cultivation. He is responsible for providing for the home's expenses and he seeks to offer his two young children a better quality of life. Agricultural work in the tropics is very hard, and he intends to improve and increase production with a loan that will help him accomplish his goals. He demonstrates a lot of effort and hard work at his job, which he does for the majority of the day, but also has time to care for his children and teach them about his work so that someday in the future they will be able to support themselves financially and improve their quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Improved banana production

loans.name: Flamingo Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Flamingo” group. They are small-scale businesspeople based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 1,500,000 for each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Alex K., pictured on the left. Alex is age 46 and was born in Makeni. He is married with 3 children who are attending primary school.  For 8 years now, Alex has been selling medicines. This loan will assist Alex to improve his business as he will use it to buy more drugs to add to his current stock.

loans.use: Buy more medicines to add to his current stock

loans.name: Marietou

texts.fr: Mariétou C. est une femme de 21 ans, elle est célibataire sans enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de BAYOUF-PALAL depuis le 15 septembre 2008, elle a une ancienneté de 1 an et demi dans le Banc Villageois et a 4 fois de suite bénéficié de crédit. Elle s'exerce a faire un petit commerce d'habits, de chaussures et d'écharpes. Elle est très travailleuse, en une année et demi elle a pu réaliser un bon niveau d'épargne. Son nouveau prêt lui permettra de mieux développer son activité en achetant plus de marchandises et réaliser des bénéfices afin d'augmenter son épargne et de prendre en charge ses besoins personnels.
texts.en:
Mariétou C., 21, is single and has no children. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois of BAYOUF-PALAL since September 15, 2008, so she has a senority of one and a half years in the Banc Villageois and has received four consecutive loans. She has a little business selling clothing, shoes, and scarves. She works hard and in one and a half years she has been able to put aside a tidy sum in savings. Her new loan will allow her to better develop her business by buying more merchandise. She expects to make profit with which she can increase her savings and support herself.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: develop and promote her income-generating business

loans.name: Kha

texts.en: Mrs. Kha S. is a young woman and the mother of two small children. One is enrolled in school, and the other one is not yet attending school. She distills white wine to sell. Additionally, she uses the leftovers from distilling to feed a few pigs. She has another great earner in her husband, who sells ice cream. He also buys chopped wood in bulk to resell for a profit. In addition to their current jobs, the couple takes time to cultivate a rice crop when the farming season comes. Kha S. is lacking some supplies to use on her field and is asking for a Kiva loan. She will use the loan to pay for the fee of plowing farmland and to purchase fertilizer, insecticide, and seed to plant.

loans.use: To pay for plowing farmland and to purchase fertilizer, insecticide, and seed

loans.name: Hafizahon's Group

texts.en: Aravan village is located in the famous vast Fergana valley, which is a homeland for many nationalities such as Kyrgyzs, Uzbeks, Tajiks and other cultures. It has its own unique and distinguished way of life, customs and mentality. For many centuries, this region has been sought after for colonization by Great Britain and Russia, but now it is a border region between Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan. Hafizahon H. lives in Aravan village. She is 32 and has two children. Both her 14-year-old daughter and 12-year-old son go to the local middle school. Hafizahon and her husband want to give their children quality education. To provide for the family, her husband works as a cook in a local café. As for Hafizahon, she combines several jobs. Hafizahon grows and sells rice, which is the main crop in this region. As well as that, she works as a nurse in a kindergarten and also sells gold jewelry and clothes. Fifteen years ago she obtained a piece of land and started growing rice. Since then, her labor has allowed them to build a new house, furnish it and provide it with conveniences. Hafizahon has applied for this loan to purchase mineral fertilizers and clothes to sell Hafizahon’s partners Sharipahon H., 35, is married and has a daughter. She sells women’s clothes. She needs this loan to purchase new clothes. Another of Hafizahon’s partner also sells clothes. She has a daughter and her husband works as an accountant in a bus station. Her intention in obtaining this loan is to increase her turnover and purchase new clothes. Gulbarchyn S., 20, is married. She is a student at Osh State University. She works as a saleswoman in a private business. Gulbarchyn needs this loan for her own needs. The last of Hafizahon’s partners, Muminjan K., 35, is the father of two children. To provide for the family, he provides law services. Muminjan has long been planning repairs to his house. Therefore, he needs a loan to purchase cement and pebbles for construction. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers for farming and some clothes to sell

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua K. sells fresh cassava and fish in Abura. She has no educational background. She is a single parent taking care of four children and is responsible for paying her children’s tuition fees and utility bills.

Efua’s loan will be used to buy more foodstuffs to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to provide a meaningful education for her children.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Mary Fe

texts.en:
Mary Fe O. is from the village of Bato Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 27 years old. Mary Fe is the one wearing stripes pink sleeveless with a black tops. Mary Fe is married and has 2 infant children. To make a living, Mary Fe owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste, powdered soap, canned goods, salt, sugar, and oil, etc.  in the local community. Mary Fe has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Mary Fe joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.
